content:
Hi,

I'm wondering what sort of profunctors M:Cop×D→SetM:C^{\text{op}}\times D \to \text{Set}M:Cop×D→Set and N:Dop×C→SetN:D^{\text{op}}\times C \to \text{Set}N:Dop×C→Set form an adjunction internal to Prof\text{Prof}Prof. By this I mean that there are natural transformations η:HomC⇒M⊗N\eta:\text{Hom}_C\Rightarrow M\otimes Nη:HomC​⇒M⊗N and ϵ:N⊗M⇒HomD\epsilon: N\otimes M \Rightarrow \text{Hom}_Dϵ:N⊗M⇒HomD​ satisfying the triangle identities.

nLab has a enigmatic remark about "semifunctors" in this situation but I'm not sure how a semifunctor would specify a profunctor.

In my own thinking, so far I have concluded that for all c∈Cc\in Cc∈C, M(c,−)M(c,-)M(c,−) and N(−,c)N(-,c)N(−,c) must be quotients of representables, but that's all I have so far.

Here is the argument for the last claim:

For f:c→c′f:c\to c'f:c→c′, denote ηc,c′(f):=(η1(f),η2(f))‾\eta_{c,c'}(f):=\overline{(\eta_1(f),\eta_2(f))}ηc,c′​(f):=(η1​(f),η2​(f))​.

Consider one of the triangle identities: (M≅HomC⊗M⇒η⊗MM⊗N⊗M⇒M⊗ϵM⊗HomD≅M)=idM(M\cong \text{Hom}_C\otimes M\xRightarrow{\eta\otimes M} M \otimes N\otimes M \xRightarrow{M\otimes \epsilon} M\otimes\text{Hom}_D\cong M) = id_M(M≅HomC​⊗Mη⊗M​M⊗N⊗MM⊗ϵ​M⊗HomD​≅M)=idM​.

Take any m:M(c,d)m:M(c,d)m:M(c,d) and run it through this identity:

m↦(idc,m)‾↦(η1(idc),η2(idc),m)‾↦(η1(idc),ϵ(η2(idc),m‾))‾↦M(idc,ϵ(η2(idc),m‾))(η1(idc))m\mapsto \overline{(\text{id}_c,m)} \mapsto \overline{(\eta_1(\text{id}_c), \eta_2(\text{id}_c), m)} \mapsto \overline{(\eta_1(\text{id}_c), \epsilon(\overline{\eta_2(\text{id}_c),m}))}\mapsto M(\text{id}_c, \epsilon(\overline{\eta_2(\text{id}_c),m}))(\eta_1(\text{id}_c))m↦(idc​,m)​↦(η1​(idc​),η2​(idc​),m)​↦(η1​(idc​),ϵ(η2​(idc​),m​))​↦M(idc​,ϵ(η2​(idc​),m​))(η1​(idc​))

By the identity, we must have m=M(idc,ϵ(η2(idc),m‾))(η1(idc))m = M(\text{id}_c, \epsilon(\overline{\eta_2(\text{id}_c),m}))(\eta_1(\text{id}_c))m=M(idc​,ϵ(η2​(idc​),m​))(η1​(idc​)). So then every m:M(c,d)m:M(c,d)m:M(c,d) is the result of a DDD-action of the single element η1(idc)\eta_1(\text{id}_c)η1​(idc​), which only depends on ccc. Thus there is a surjective transformation D(d,−)⇒M(c,−)D(d,-)\Rightarrow M(c,-)D(d,−)⇒M(c,−), where ddd is the codomain of η1(idc)\eta_1(\text{id}_c)η1​(idc​), sending h:d→d′h:d\to d'h:d→d′ to M(idc,h)(η1(idc))M(\text{id}_c, h)(\eta_1(\text{id}_c))M(idc​,h)(η1​(idc​)).

A similar argument can be made for N(−,c)N(-, c)N(−,c).

Talking about semifunctors is just a cute trick for talking about functors to the Cauchy completion. If F:C→DF:C\to DF:C→D is a semifunctor, then the image of each identity F(idc)F(\mathrm{id}_c)F(idc​) is not necessarily an identity, but it is idempotent, and thus FFF induces an actual functor into the Cauchy completion of DDD. And oppositely.

So the Cauchy completion D→D‾D\to\overline{D}D→D sends all idempotents to identity? I thought it just makes all idempotents split.

But how does any of this give a profunctor?

I didn't mean that the composite C→FD→D‾C \xrightarrow{F} D \to \overline{D}CF​D→D is a functor, only that from FFF you can define a functor C→D‾C\to \overline{D}C→D, by sending an object c∈Cc\in Cc∈C to the splitting of the idempotent F(idc)F(\mathrm{id}_c)F(idc​).
Once you have such a functor, you get a profunctor C×D‾op→SetC\times \overline{D}^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathrm{Set}C×Dop→Set in the usual way, and then restrict to C×DopC\times D^{\mathrm{op}}C×Dop.

Since Set\mathrm{Set}Set has split idempotents, functors C×D‾op→SetC\times \overline{D}^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathrm{Set}C×Dop→Set are equivalent to functors C×Dop→SetC\times {D}^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathrm{Set}C×Dop→Set, so the restriction doesn't lose any information.
